Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-30 23:29

I just found out about the difficulties that #PrivacyTools is currently experiencing. It sounds like they may have to eventually shutdown their Mastodon instance (as well as PeerTube and Matrix), which is not great for their users. Unfortunately, they don't have a lot of options. Whether they're going to fire those back up under a new domain is still under discussion. I hope their users can migrate off to some other instance, and of course they're welcome here.

https://blog.privacytools.io/the-future-of-privacytools/

Then I forget about it and end up having to fix it again years later.

M: A car.

M: A cat.
H: No
M: A house.
H: No
M: A cloud.
H: No
M: A star.

M: A computer.

M: A shoe.

M: A sock.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-22 04:49

@fishfulpenguin It really depends on how flexible you are with your device. It's a new platform, so it doesn't have ALL the stuff. It's also significantly cheaper than most other smart watches on the market, and it's an open platform. If something isn't here that you want, you're able to create it. If you want something more polished, this is probably not going to work for you.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-21 03:03

@fishfulpenguin The one I have is one of the Dev units, so it's not sealed. This means the only way to get the back to stay on (and the battery in place) is to glue the back on, or find some other way to keep pressure on it. There are 3d print models that will do it, but they're all pretty clunky. It's made it fun to play with but not sure great for an actual watch. I just bought a new one that's actually pre-sealed, which means I'll have one for toying and one for wearing.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-19 17:17

@aphyr I'm glad it finally worked its way out. Let me know if you experience that kind of glitch again. I've never heard of that before, and I'd like to be able to see if we can come up with a fix while it's in progress.

@jamesnvc @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-19 17:16

@jonasvautherin Yep, #Mycroft has made use of their data set to train their speech models. I'm actually a big fan and have done both reading and validation for them in my spare time. Unfortunately with the big players having so much data at their disposal through various means, it becomes very difficult for other products to compete. #CommonVoice is a good way for smaller projects to get the data and analysis they need without the #privacy violation.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-16 00:06

@alexbuzzbee "though I'm not sure what the point of a smartwatch that doesn't integrate with something else would be"

This is actually a selling point for me. One of the things I hate about smart watches as they are is all the data on them is sent home to the company that created them. Fitbit belongs to Google. Samsung and Google have a deal. Apple owns the Apple watch. All these companies are gathering way too much data. I'd much rather have a suite of tools to analyze that data locally.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-14 20:12

@can I don't tame it. I let it loose and hope that it doesn't bite my face off.

Delete files: rm filename
Delete directories: rmdir dirname
Delete directories containing stuff: rm -rf dirname (this one is the dangerous one)

Nothing special and probably the same methods as 98% of all Linux users (stat made up on the spot with no information).

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-12 01:23

Recently my friend and cofounder of #Fosstodon posted a blog post about how he's no longer using #Linux on the desktop. The reaction from the community was a good one, so I figured that I could safely announce something myself that wouldn't illicit too much hate.

So, here goes....

I cut off a large part of my beard....

Please don't hate me.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-10 21:17

How my day is going so far.

#coffee

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-10 05:32

@indie@mas.to My head has been throbbing for hours. I'm thinking tonight might be an early to bed, late to rise kind of night.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-09 19:38

@Tay0 The problem comes from the fact that the people making these requests don't understand why it's not the best idea to have an internal process access another internal server through an external interface. I mean, it does work. It's just like going from San Francisco to Los Angeles by way of New York.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-09 18:48

Understanding your environment is important for everybody in a process! This is a literal request I received:

Transfer a file from an Azure blob to a SFTP server so an internal server can use an Internet facing service to pick up that file and transfer it to another internal server that then processes it, places the output back on the SFTP server through the Internet facing service so an internal process can pick it up though the Internet facing service and transfer it back out to the blob.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-08 20:18

@JohanEmpa Yea, but that's from last year, and I don't think that's related to the stuff #Mycroft currently has going on. It's always nice to see, don't get me wrong.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-07-08 20:17

Customer: "Can you expedite this request? We've been unable to do this task for over two months."

Me: "Soooo.... you haven't been able to do it for two months, and you want me to drop everything I'm already working on that was planned and done the right way for something that's been broken for months that you all of a sudden want fixed immediately??"

This is a paraphrased conversation, but not by much. üò†

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-28 15:51

Apple's store is much more restrictive than even Google's, and last I checked (admittedly it's been a while) jailbreaking an iOS device was significantly harder than side loading an Android app. Wider ranging ramifications as well.

I've seen more image of Jupiter and Saturn than I can count, but there's something dramatically different about seeing them yourself with your own eyes, even if it's through a telescope.
Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-25 23:32

@kev That's been kind of my impression too. Plus some of Brave's behavior in the past has been "questionable" in my opinion, so it would require something more than prettier graphics (IMHO) to get me to switch. I'm not seeing it.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-12 02:17

@arivigo

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-11 23:59

Testing out Cutefish today. I'm not a huge fan of it, but mostly because I'm not a huge fan of macOS, and this DE is a little too faithful to the original. If you're a macOS fan, it might be just your speed. When it's finished that is. It's definitely not entirely ready yet.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-11 23:57

@arivigo Honestly, I think you'd still see it. The "Unlisted" option for replies seems entirely redundant. I think even when that issue was opened it was redundant. The Home timeline isn't a public timeline, it's unique to each account. There's not a configuration option that I'm aware of that makes replies show up in a public timeline.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-11 23:21

@arivigo No, it's not true that replies NEVER show in public timelines, but close enough for that particular issue. Replies will show up in your Home timeline (not the local timeline) if you follow both parties. If someone you follow replies to someone else you follow, you'll see it.

Why that issue was created? No clue. It's almost four years old, and even then people commented that replies were already unlisted.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 20:28

@ssafar Honestly, taking Twitter out of the conversation here, this is something that should be added as a feature. We have the ability to block media attachments entirely as part of our federation options, but we should be able to disable caching on an instance by instance basis. That would be handy for things like pixelfed.social where there's nothing inherently wrong with the content, other than the fact that it adds up fast on the drives.

@kev @RyuKurisu @Spaceface16518

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 20:22

@ssafar Nope. I found one user from a remote instance where no one from #Fosstodon followed them, but they still had a little over 2MB of cached images on our system.

@kev @RyuKurisu @Spaceface16518

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 19:45

@kev I picked some random accounts out of the Federated timeline that I'd never seen before, and they had between 1 and 12MB of cached media files on Fosstodon. That's just the pictures they've posted. If we average (ish), and assume each remote user would have 5MB of images, it would only require 200,000 remote users to generate another TB of storage for us. Twitter has an estimated 350 million active users. That's 1750TB of storage. Not accurate, but close enough.

@RyuKurisu @Spaceface16518

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 05:34

@Spaceface16518 It sure seems that way doesn't it?

@RyuKurisu @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 05:33

@thumb Yep, that's exactly what it was. It was working fine for MONTHS without the slashes on the end of those links. Never had an issue. Thanks for all the help!

@joeligj12 @josias@theres.life @celia

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 05:18

@thumb Yep, you're right. Sorry about that. Literacy not one of my strengths apparently.

(everybody who has ever read my blog: DUH mike)

I tried your simplified code, but the results were exactly the same. It's live right now if you'd like to look.

@joeligj12 @josias@theres.life @celia

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 05:13

@RyuKurisu Some of it. I'm not sure what percentage it is. For example, @kev and I were the first 2 users on Fosstodon. Kev is literally user #1. Since he's in the UK and I'm in the US, he started his account and then started following people he liked. That opened up Fosstodon to federation (kinda the point). When I joined Fosstodon as the second OFFICIAL @fosstodon user, I'm not #2, I'm #32. The other 31 people are stuff that got synced across from other instances.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-05 05:08

Mike Stone @mike 2021-06-03 21:25

@SciencePhysicist Heh, well, we keep the data, but my team handles transfers between our company and other companies. Data gets extracted, encrypted, and sent through a variety of ways. When they ask me for a file, they're asking for the file that was extracted from the DB to send to someone else. We still have that data in the DB. That's why we can get away with the 90 days. They're just not wanting to do the work to do the extract again.

Me: Uh, no. We have a 90 day retention policy.

Them: Sooooo, it's gone?

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-22 06:50

@ryo It is when Apple gets 100% of the app store sales on their platform. At least that's Epic's argument. Epic is alleging that Apple holds a monopoly on the distribution of iOS apps, not that iOS is a monopoly itself. It's hard to deny that's true.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-22 05:31

@ryo Android may have 76% worldwide, but they are still trailing here in the United States. Apple and Epic are American companies, and the suit is in an American court. Worldwide market share is not going to matter as much as the market share in the United States.

Epic is absolutely in it for the money, but they haven't hidden that. The monopoly in question here is the app store. Apple controls the platform, and they control every app that has access to it.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-22 05:27

@RyuKurisu Of course.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-21 17:58

@TheFreePenguin I think people find the registrations attractive because of the "verifyability" of those kinds of services. You can be at least a little sure that the person you're talking to is the same person you talked to last week with the same name. IRC (and by extension any service that doesn't require registration) kind of doesn't offer that assurance. It used to annoy the heck out of me when someone from my friends list would sign on, but then it wouldn't be them.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-21 17:56

@hund I remember back in the 90s the big three were DALnet, Undernet, and EFnet. DALnet was pretty small at the time if I recall correctly. I was on Undernet because it felt like a good midway between DALnet and EFnet. I don't think I've ever been on QuakeNet.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-20 23:08

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-05 21:03

@TheFreePenguin OK, the reason for that is a new feature (at the time) was announced allowing us to obfuscate the names of domains getting blocked. We tried it out, and didn't think anybody would care enough to go back and change it. If you'd like us to unobfuscate it, we absolutely are can do that.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-05 20:28

@TheFreePenguin Can you clarify this question? Are you talking about the about/more page or something else?

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-05 17:32

@hund If by "see" you mean I can detect a big blue thing above me, then yes, I can see the sky without my glasses. More detail requires spectacles.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-05 17:30

@murtezayesil They're similar, I"ll give you that, but no. Hashes are the same size regardless of input. If you hash the letter A or the entirety of this reply, you're going to get the same size output. That's not true of encryption. Even if it were, being able to decrypt is a fundamental feature of encryption. It's not encryption if it can't be decoded. Rather than hashing being one way encryption, something you can't decrypt after it's encrypted is just a really crappy hash.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-05 00:17

@scylla Why can't you?

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-04 22:10

@evandornbusch Need to replace that useless chain with a USB cable. Looks good though.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-04 20:28

I find the number of UFOs I spot in the sky increases dramatically when I'm not wearing my glasses.

@XxAlexXx

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-04 19:48

Mike Stone @mike 2021-05-04 16:23

Customer: Can we encrypt the logs from the DB server?
Me: Sure, we can encrypt the not currently being written to files.
C: And if we need to look at them, we can decrypt those files, right?
M: ........ yes.

Do I need to explain that there's no fundamental difference between encrypting to the point it CAN'T be decrypted, and just deleting the file.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-20 21:42

@Spaceface16518 Solid advice. Thanks!

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-20 21:27

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-20 21:25

OK, this feels too easy, and so I'm super paranoid about it. Anybody see anything wrong with this? I don't want to blow some of this stuff up.

#!/bin/ksh

ARCHIVE_LOCATION="~/ARCHIVES"
ARCHIVE_DATE=`date +%Y%m%d`

find /sftp/* -type f -mtime +365 | while read LINE
do
tar -rf ${ARCHIVE_LOCATION}/archive_${ARCHIVE_DATE}.tar "${LINE}"
rm -f "${LINE}"
done

gzip -9 ${ARCHIVE_LOCATION}/archive_${ARCHIVE_DATE}.tar

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-15 20:33

@david Yea, that's really the problem. The devices should blend in and be mostly invisible. They're intended to behave like appliances. You don't want cables running everywhere and stuff poking out all over the place. It should be something self contained and virtually invisible until it's needed. That #PineCube looks perfect. If only the hardware had a little bit more juice.

@PINE64 @linmob

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-15 19:03

@linmob Yea, I've been looking to build one as #Mycroft hasn't been the most expedient when it comes to shipping their hardware. I've got a couple Raspberry Pis running around the house, and I've been looking at what it would take to get a decent microphone/speaker combination setup that wouldn't be super weird looking. I'd much rather have something that's decent and integrated, but so far the #Pinephone has been the best thing I've found. Honestly, it works flawlessly as a Mycroft.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-12 19:59

@unl0ckd I don't have a list. Maybe I should make one, but being completely lazy I can point to the FSFE, FSFI, and FSFLA, which are all separate, unaffiliated organizations. The FSFE has come out condemning Stallman's election, and said they will not be involved with the FSF in any way. Other organizations donations could be directed towards are Creative Commons, Mozilla, the GNOME Foundation, the Open Source Collective, or the Document Foundation.

@sneak

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-12 19:21

@unl0ckd Or pull their support from the FSF and give it to another, pre-existing organization. That's what I've seen the majority of people who disagree with RMS's election do.

@sneak

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-12 19:12

@unl0ckd Not to be the pessimist, but I doubt it. Whether you agree with them or not, a large percentage of the #FOSS community thinks that the FSF just installed someone who has no business being there, and all they've done is say, "Sorry, we shouldn't have done it that way. We're not changing our minds, but we REALLY promise not to do it again. Really."

@sneak

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-12 18:55

@unl0ckd The problem comes in when you consider the optics of this whole scenario. RMS's "apology" isn't really an apology. The FSF's statement comes across as a "It's better to ask forgiveness than permission", and there are a lot of people that don't think RMS should be in that kind of a position based on his prior behavior. The fact that the FSF made all these "mistakes" while putting RMS in a position of authority could suggest to some that the FSF leadership shouldn't be leaders.

@sneak

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-12 18:36

@unl0ckd I think "Yes" is the proper answer to those questions.

The FSF statement claims RMS acknowledges he made mistakes, but the linked statement from RMS reads like an excuse, or charitably "an explanation". I don't see a lot of regret being expressed. Maybe he regrets people not understanding his intentions. Who knows.

The messaging, pr, and transparency were abysmal for the entire process. Feelings about RMS aside, that's hard to not recognize.

@sneak

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-08 18:25

@Tay0 I think there's moderation tools in FediLab, but honestly I just use the browser version, even on mobile. It's just easier in the long run (for me).

@kev @cooper

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-07 23:04

@Tay0 Awesome! Glad to hear it. I've elevated your permissions level to moderator, so feel free to click in there and look around. There's not currently any open reports, but if you have any questions let us know. Also, hit either myself (mikestone) or Kev (kevq) up on Keybase to get added to the moderator chat there. It's where we discuss things that may be in gray areas (or just things that strike our fancy any given day).

@kev @cooper

Mike Stone @mike 2021-04-07 00:01

@Tay0 It's a relatively straight forward process. There are two things that we're going to want you to do. There will be reports that come in for various things. Obvious things you can take the appropriate action. If you have questions you can always hit up @kev, @cooper, or myself or we can discuss it in the Keybase chat. The other thing is we're going to be turning on approval requirements for people to open accounts. This is just a way to weed out obvious spam accounts. If unsure let them in.

@Jase Honestly, his own words are much more damning than anything I've read in the petitions I've seen.

I can see your logic regarding membership to the FSF, but I also get no impression there's flexibility on this matter. As members, they're more inclined to listen to you, but if enough people drop their membership then they're forced to listen to their wallets.

Neither is a particularly good choice in this particular instance since it is so polarizing.

The list "prostitution, adultery, necrophilia, bestiality, possession of child pornography, and even incest and pedophilia" is a direct copy and paste, and can be found less than 10 lines into the page. Or you can hit CTRL-F, paste it in, and the browser will take you right to it.

Me: I need to get this access granted so I can do thing_1 because there's no one else who can do it.

Person: Hm, OK. We should have a meeting to discuss this request. Please invite your other_person who would be responsible for doing this task.

Me: The reason I'm making this request is because THERE IS NO OTHER_PERSON.

Me: *frustrated_sigh*

Mike Stone @mike 2021-03-14 21:02

Day 15 of the #100DaysToOffload 2021 Series:

Lots of people actually trust Google. I trust Google to take as much of my information as they can and use it however they choose. Beyond that, blindly trusting the results of any search engine is probably not the best idea.

https://mikestone.me/trust-in-google/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-03-14 20:07

@blueberry OK, I thought maybe I was the weird one again. Sometimes when I see this stuff on the screen all the time, but not heard out loud, my pronunciations are... odd. It could work over time with CS students maybe. I think if you wanted it to work in general conversations, you'd have to go with an easier way to pronounce it. Like Xerox, or xylophone. I could see xor working that way.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-03-09 21:30

@AAMfP Honestly, I used write.as for a while on my blog, paid for the premium, everything, but they never really have gotten the federation stuff working. I had my own domain and that only worked for a little bit and then failed. They "worked on it" for over six months with no solution before I moved off the platform. In my experience, it's a fine blogging platform, but the federation is alpha quality at best.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-03-09 15:22

@the_codebalion I'd heard of the NFT thing, but honestly I don't know a lot about it. We could put something into our CoC, but I don't know how that would work. The NFT is on a particular blockchain, and I don't know how that supposedly ties back to a particular "item" on it's original system. For items such as social media posts, how would we know if an NFT of one of our posts was "sold"? Or multiple NFTs on various systems?

@matt @kev @write_as @hund @dajbelshaw

Mike Stone @mike 2021-03-09 00:03

@AAMfP OK, I suspended the account, physically told the instance to delete any and all data that was cached about the account. After that was complete, I unsuspended the account and refreshed the profile. If that doesn't do it, I'm not sure what will. That's about the most extreme measure we can take.

@matt @kev @write_as @hund @dajbelshaw

Mike Stone @mike 2021-03-08 21:34

@AAMfP Did a refresh of the remote profile. The only other thing we could potentially do is suspend the account temporarily and then unsuspend it. Doing that would remove all local cached files. That should NOT be necessary though. Give it another go and let me know how it works (or doesn't).

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-15 00:09

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-15 00:09

@rw It seems pretty straight forward. It's got the typical "Appley" bar at the bottom and upper left menu. Category break down. The version I'm using is pretty eye candy intensive, but it would probably be fine for a intermediate user. It's Arch based, but it's got the software manager and everything is super straight forward to use.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-13 19:09

@ru@smallcamp.art @kev I loved the circles. I feel like they kind of lost that in v2. It was still there, but kind of buried. G+ joke:

Tell Circle_1: I just got a really great new job that all I'll be starting after some stuff at the old job gets completed.

Tell Circle_2: I'm terminally ill.

Wait

Tell both circles: Tomorrow is my last day.

Watch the chaos.

Not sure if anybody ever really tried this IRL. Probably not.

@TechZerker @techzerker@librem.one That's a really interesting question, and one I think you've probably hit the nail on the head with. Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-10 17:05

@randynose Heh, it actually happened while I was there in my school. When I was a freshman, there were no computers. All typewriters. If you were lucky, you got an electric so you didn't have to constantly clear the arms. The second half of my freshman year, they got their first computers. Two of them that everybody had to share. We each got a couple weeks to use them per year. By the time I was a senior, there were multiple computer labs. I even got to help set one up.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 22:43

@nd@x0r.be If I told you I only had two meetings today and did nothing else, it would seem like I slacked the day away. I DID only have two meetings today. One from 9:00AM to noon, and the other from 1:00PM to 5:00PM. That's all I've been doing all day.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 17:08

@Sandra I had a typewriter as well (electric) I got in high school. I didn't get a computer until my Junior year, and even then my "online" activities were just some local BBSs. My HS was going to offer a programming class, but it got cancelled when only myself and one other student registered. Instead I took Computer Applications, which basically taught me how to use Word Perfect 5.1 and some other equivalent applications. I didn't get access to a *nix system till college.

@Gina @tinyrabbit

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 09:55

@Sandra I was 19 as well, and I'll give IRC most of the credit. I learned some in high school, but it never really clicked until my IRC days.

@Gina @tinyrabbit

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 09:52

@Sandra Ours was almost entirely qbasic, but there was a little bit of bat in there to control screen echos. The first versions didn't have that, and something echoed to the screen when the script ended that kind of have away the game.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 08:56

@Gina There were a couple "sample" games that came with qbasic at the time (which was already installed for students to use for class) called Nibbles (I think anyway) and Gorillas. We started out super basic and dug into the code to figure out some of the other bits. No one showed us how back then.

@sotolf

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 08:50

@lopeztel We got a Novel Network I THINK my junior year. It's been a long time. Can't quite remember.

@Gina

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 08:45

@sotolf We didn't "have" keyloggers, we made it. We wrote a qbasic script that looked and acted like the login screen, and we put it on computers that actually had hard drives (maybe 50% of them), and then we waited until the teacher tried to login with the admin password on one. It saved the password off to our home directory, told her she typed the password wrong, and then kicked her to the actual login screen. It was primitive, but it actually worked.

@Gina

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-08 08:28

@Gina I, on the other hand, dutifully completed all of my typing courses in high school, during which I got into massive and continuous trouble for constantly keylogging the instructors admin account so I always had full access to our school network. I suppose things worked out in the end.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-07 20:28

@stardust That's funny since I'm a huge fan of Vivaldi and it's my primary browser.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-04 00:49

@zigpress I hope he doesn't mind me throwing him under the bus here, but @kelbot just did a migration not that long ago. He might have some insight into the process that I don't.

@chris @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-03 23:33

@zigpress When the documentation says something different than I do, believe the documentation.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-03 21:01

@artfulsodger Mentions and replies are not treated the same way by the system. A reply won't show up in the local timeline, but a message that mentions another user immediately that LOOKS like a reply still will. Also, I believe that a reply to your own toot will still show up in the local timeline. Non-English in the local timeline can and should be reported, though if it's not a constant and willful thing it will more than likely end up as a warning.

@fosstodon @kev @cooper

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-03 17:21

@brandon Glad to hear it! Welcome back!

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-03 16:35

@oscarhall Atom. Since I migrated from write.as to Jekyll, it's how I update my website.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-03 16:33

@zigpress I'm with @kev on this one in that I've never actually done this process, but I'd expect that you should set up the new account as an alias in your Fosstodon account, and then attempt the move from the new account.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-02-02 03:06

@randynose @sbanwart @wuwei @kev I'm guessing the "Insurance" timeline was supposed to be the instance timeline, which is the local timeline. Even in the "Advanced" view you can click on the little control panel looking icon in the upper right of the timeline header and click the Unpin option to remove it from your view. I've done that and I don't miss it in the slightest. If you see any content that you think is inappropriate in the local timeline, PLEASE report it.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-18 09:35

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-17 21:49

@ndanes I'm still working on this, but I've made some changes to the blog.md @kev included in his tutorial. To say it looks bad is an understatement, but it does what I want (uglyily). Now I've got to make it pretty before letting anybody else see it.

https://mikestone.me/blog

@thumb

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-17 21:01

@ndanes I'm probably going to go with something like this. I was talking to @kev two nights ago about the front page. Write.as automatically has pagination, and I didn't think about that when I moved over to Jekyll, so now everything I ever posted is on the front page. I was thinking of implementing paging (which Jekyll supports), but honestly a simple archive page feels just as good. All it needs to be is a list of titles and dates. No needs to get all fancy with it.

@thumb

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-17 20:58

@carl I'll probably give it a look. Right now I'm debating between using your solution for Mastodon comments or just not having comments at all. I haven't had comments on the pages for a while now, and I'm not really missing them. I can see value in having them though.

@xosem@toot.site @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-17 20:54

@greenpete I'd actually disagree. Jekyll itself is just a tiny app that runs on a PC. It's just a way of generating a static site from markdown, giving you an easy way to create and edit files that is easier than writing HTML, but can run on basically any hosting platform. I went with the tutorial @kev wrote, so I'm using Netlify with a Github back end, but that's just hosting. In theory I could host this on a Pi in my house.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-17 10:16

@xosem@toot.site My question was more about the order of events. With Jekyll, it's looking like I'm going to have to be putting the post ID (with the link to my blog post) into the front matter. Is that right? I have to create the post on Mastodon prior to actually creating the blog post? The order of events feels backwards there.

@kev @carl

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-17 07:42

@andrewnoyes Hi.

I'll be playing around with that more later to see what's going on there, but for now gedit is good. Atom is a little heavy for me personally.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 17:22

@nd@x0r.be Right now she's building what looks to be some kind of torture chamber in Minecraft. Complete with a drop into the infinite abyss (not really) that's below the bedrock. I can only assume that's for disposing of the corpses of her enemies.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 17:20

@nd@x0r.be For a while in the 90s, I called Dell so often they'd recognize me.

Them: Dell technical support.
Me: Yea, this is Mike Stone with Company Name, and I have a dead motherboard.
Them: Have you..... oh..... just a second... we're sending you a new motherboard.

It really streamlined the process. I kinda miss those days?

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 17:16

It's hard doing even the most remedial of IT tasks when you have a four year old playing with your hair and tapping you on the head. Occasionally putting a finger in your eye.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 09:01

@XxAlexXx Federated is everybody on every instance, which is several million people. Local is the people here on Fosstodon, which is just shy of 15,000.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 08:48

@piggo Yea, that part I do kind of miss. We used to feed the chickens a lot of grass, and something about that darkened the egg yolk to something where the yellow was so dark it was almost orange. Much more flavorful than the eggs I get in the store.

@Gina

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 08:45

@piggo Ooof, they stink when you defeather them. I don't have a lot of experience with sheep thankfully. I'm hoping to keep it that way for the forever future.

@Gina

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 08:42

@Gina I grew up on a chicken farm. I'm pretty happy to have 0 live chickens in my life. Our neighbors about a mile or two down the road had goats. I still remember the smell when the wind was right. Pretty happy to be a thousand miles from there too.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-13 03:51

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-12 22:36

@sanchez I probably use it in the worst way it could be used. I do use it for file management and some other small things, but it's been the best terminal app for me. I just don't like other apps in Windows. I used to use PuTTY, but I just found I liked WSL better. That's a horribly stupid thing to use WSL for, but it works for me.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-12 22:15

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-12 21:51

@rebel_luddite@social.linux.pizza Hmm, it's never been a problem, but then I work with almost exclusively .tar.gz or .zip, and it's easy to remember how to deal with those two. That's a much, MUCH worse option.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-12 17:21

@ianthetechie the same subjects you'd avoid discussing with your family around Thanksgiving dinner. Religion, politics, etc. We just ask that you keep your conversations polite and if you feel that something may be something that other members of our instance don't want to see or hear about, make use of the CW feature.

As always, if you have any questions or concerns about your own content or content you see on our timeline, don't hesitate to ask @kev or myself, or any of our mod team. 2/2

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-12 17:18

@ianthetechie It's perfectly normal and acceptable to have multiple accounts on various instances. I know several people who do that, one of which I lose track of just how many instances he's on.

That being said, it's fine to post non-FOSS stuff on Fosstodon (within reason). Our instance is for fans of free and open source software, but we don't expect that to be the only thing that ever gets posted about. There are some subjects we'd prefer to avoid. Those subjects are pretty much 1/

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-07 23:00

@NatCor I've never used either, so I can't speak personally, but it's hard to get people to migrate once they've settled in. Friendica and Hubzilla could be head and shoulders above Facebook, but until people are there no one else is going to want to go there. It's a self perpetuating situation. It's something I'm hoping to see the Fediverse kind of remedy, since it allows for a "New" social network to tap into the existing userbase of other Federated systems.

Mike Stone @mike 2021-01-02 00:35

@mgiagante @thumb I'm guessing it has something to do with this:

"Keybase verification is irreversible. Keybase uses an immutable signature chain for its identity proofs, so once you prove your identity on Keybase, you cannot remove it. You can only revoke your proof by signing a revocation message with your associated private key."

From here:

https://docs.joinmastodon.org/user/contacts/

I wasn't aware that was the case, and it's pretty annoying if that's true and the Keybase line can't be removed.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-12 22:09

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-12 22:08

@mehdi I use a tool called Variety to periodically change my wallpaper to a random choice from several different sources. It's pretty cool. All this script does is take the current wallpaper and add that image to the Favorites directory for Variety. Favorites are selected at a higher than random chance, so you'll see those more often. Normally there's a GUI interface for that, but it doesn't work in Gnome, so I have to go through a series of menus and I find that whole process annoying.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 22:37

It's 3:30PM on a Friday. Time to put on the headphones, crank the volume, and rest my head on the back of my chair.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 22:30

@indixotic@x0r.be I only looked at a little of the timeline, and pretty much decided that I didn't want to read any more.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 22:28

@indixotic@x0r.be Seems warranted.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 22:23

@indixotic@x0r.be Which instance?

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 22:19

Sometimes the simple scripts can be super useful. I tied this one to a keyboard shortcut. There's probably an easier way to do it, but this was easier and more fun.

#!/bin/bash

fileLine=2
workingFile="/home/mike/.config/variety/history.txt"
favLocation="/home/mike/Pictures/Variety/Favorites/"

fileLocal=`head -1 ${workingFile}`
fileLine=`expr ${fileLine} + ${fileLocal}`
fileName=`head -${fileLine} ${workingFile}|tail -1`
cp ${fileName} ${favLocation}

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 21:17

@brunofontes Oh yea, those are fun.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 20:58

@ColinTheMathmo I admit I was pretty annoyed by the whole thing. All the "Client" comments prior to my response were during my lunch. They messaged me five different times, three different ways, including texting my cell phone. Then they kept me waiting for hours after it was SO urgent.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 20:52

@Gina Youch. VM with a VPN time.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 20:51

Client: Can you do this thing?
Client: Can you do this thing?
Client: Can you do this thing right now?
Client: We really need you to do this thing.
Client: We need this thing done right now!!!
Me: OK, let me look at it.
Me: You didn't give me this bit.
Client: Oh, sorry, give me a few minutes.
Me: Twiddles thumbs for two hours.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-11 20:17

Mike Stone @mike 2020-12-07 20:53

@Matter There are a couple options. Not sure if any of them is good. We can disable the trending hashes completely. We can require hashtags to be reviewed before they are allowed to trend on Fosstodon, or we can block particular hashes. Those last two require a significant time investment from us. The first one is quick and easy and throws the baby out with the bath water. We can't do anything about Venezuelan state media specifically.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-30 17:54

@Tay0 Well, throwing out everything but logic, it makes sense. If I told you there was a pink tennis ball in your place and you need to find it, it's logically sound to say you're not terribly likely to find it if it wasn't there in the first place. On the other hand, I spend hours a day looking for things my kids have just put down SOMEWHERE in my house, usually things like TV remotes in the refrigerator. You're more likely to miss something there than find something that's not.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-30 15:33

@Tay0 Possible, but it's more rare getting a false positive. It's a lot easier to miss something that's there than find something that's not, so false negatives are much more of a thing than false positives. Still, not impossible.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-14 04:30

@humility_explorer Hi and welcome. We've made an effort to add many Linux distros as emoji. Of course we haven't gotten all of them, but the distro in people's display name is just an emoji. Just go to your Profile settings, and in the Display name, just enter : distro : (without the spaces). So, :fedora: or :ubuntu: or :arch:. If you don't find the distro you're looking for, let us know and we can add new ones too. Hope that helps!

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-14 01:54

@cb The skill is usable as soon as you create it, and is stored locally. If you're talking about #Mycroft in general, that's also possible. There's an open source version of the backend you can download and host in your own environment called Selene. I've never actually done that, though I've been interested in giving it a spin.

https://github.com/MycroftAI/selene-backend

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-10 16:27

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-10 01:35

@jocor It's not hard. It just needs to be a .png file that's less than 50K and is square. Non-square images result in the emoji being squished on one dimension or another. Colors need to be observed in some cases since some people view Mastodon in light mode, some in dark mode. Best case, the emojis will look good in both cases. Transparency is a good thing often, but other times not depending on the colors in the emoji itself.

:regolith:

In this case, I just copied the profile picture.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-09 17:19

@anzuh Hello and welcome.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-09 17:14

@john@liberdon.com Yes, the version often used by people who don't live there is wrong in both English and Spanish. :)

@codesections

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-09 15:25

@indixotic@x0r.be I have maybe five that I regularly check, and one of those is pseudo-private, so I might get 1 or 2 messages a day on it (that aren't spam). After filters, I've got ~300 messages this morning to comb through. That's since Friday.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-09 15:23

@codesections I asked my brother, the English teacher. His response:

"I haven‚Äôt looked into it, but I suspect that it is more of a formality and convention issue. Contractions are already seen as informal and would not be used in high level academic writing. Using you‚Äôre in the manner you shared would also just be unconventional. It is the kind of mistake that indicates outsider. Like people who say Ne-vah-dah. It isn‚Äôt ‚Äúwrong‚Äù but it isn‚Äôt right."

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-09 14:45

@indixotic@x0r.be I dread opening my email any day, any time. I don't have the highest opinion of email in general though, so that could just be me.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-09 00:11

@bryankentwrites Yep, the only downside is that field has a limited number of characters, and the emoji are counted by the characters in the name, not as a single character, so "ubuntu" counts as 8 characters (counting the : on each end), not one. You can fill up that field pretty quickly. Still, a fun feature.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 22:01

@jocor Sure, worst case scenario it's still going to be nice enough to be outside while we're there. Hell, I'm originally from Montana, so minus a few sand storms here and there, it's almost always nice enough to be outside when it's not summer.

@bryankentwrites

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 21:59

@jocor I'm really liking it actually. I haven't tried it on a desktop for many years, and they've really ironed everything out. It's very "Gnome", so if you don't like Gnome, you're probably not going to like Fedora, but if you're good with it, then I think you'll probably really like it.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 21:56

@bryankentwrites

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 21:47

@jocor

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 21:45

@clacke So, in that case, everybody who subscribes would get a duplicate copy of the post, just with a different video link? In that case, it wouldn't be spamming other people, but followers could be receiving a lot more than they plan on. I'm not opposed to that implementation as long as it's posting Followers Only and not posting to the public timeline. People would need to be aware that the content being sent to them may not be content they'd like to see.

@Wingy @wylel

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 21:41

@bryankentwrites

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 21:40

@jocor Well, it kind of switched for me. I tried to do an in place upgrade after the 20.10 version came out, but after a restart it came up in some kind of DDE/KDE hybrid. It was KDE, but still trying to use all the DDE tools. I tried to kind of go back and at least rearrange things so it was a full version of KDE, but it was just taking too long and mostly was just annoying me in the process. Fedora 33 came out around that time, and I figured if I was going to rebuild, I might as well play.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-11-08 21:36

@Wingy I'm not sure. I guess it would depend. Having a bot running around commenting on every YouTube link could be disruptive. Even if you're "opting in" by following, you're still commenting on someone else's post. They're going to get those responses, and those are going to be automated responses to their post. Based on the information I have at this point, I'd have to say no.

codesections @codesections 2020-11-03 16:32

Hey #fosstodon folks: the Fosstodon CoC is always important, but it might be *especially* important today. A few quotes to remember:

* Fosstodon is *not* a free speech zone
* Fosstodon is *not* an advocacy space
* Do not be intentionally antagonistic
* Do not post about inflammatory, controversial subjects without a Content Warning.

Full CoC: https://hub.fosstodon.org/code-of-conduct

Be kind to each other out there, and generous with your use of Content Warnings!

@amolith Heh, there's so many stupid things I did in this story. It was finals week, my freshman year of college. I was awake for over 4 days straight. Woke up with a dent in the side of my skull. Finished the drive, and went straight to bed. 23 hours later, I got up to eat a meal and then slept 16 more hours. Felt rested.

Son: The answer is "this" (not really what he said)
Teacher: <<Something I can't hear>>.
Son: I don't know if it's correct cause I'm kinda lazy.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-27 21:35

@jbauer Removing posts you don't like really isn't in the spirit of the #100DaysToOffload challenge. From the page:

"Posts don‚Äôt need to be long-form, deep, meaningful, or even that well written. If there are spelling and grammar mistakes, or even if there‚Äôs no real point to the post, so what? What‚Äôs important is that you‚Äôre writing about the things you want to write about."

I say keep em, regardless of whether they meet your normal standards.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-27 16:51

@trek Well, Fedora 33 just came out either today or yesterday, so I just want to try out the new release. I haven't tried Mint for a couple releases, but Fedora is a more traditional Gnome interface. It's been refined to an almost flawless experience from what I can tell in the last 10 minutes of use. If you're a fan of the Gnome interface, I'm having a hard time finding a better out of the box setup. If you don't like Gnome, you're probably not going to be happy in vanilla Fedora.

@marty I tried to do that for a while, but muscle memory really messed me up. I almost always use a clear before an ls or ls -al, so I aliased the whole thing to just mls, and I still was always typing clear;ls -al every stinking time before I realized I could just type mls -al and get the exact same thing. There are so many better ways of doing it than the way I do it, but I just can't get any of them to stick in my workflow.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-14 20:46

@thaha_jemni @blackrat It would be nice if Twitter could figure out a way to not be a cesspool of filth, but honestly I think how it's managed is a big part of that issue. The timeline is determined by an algorithm, not just a chronological list of posts of friends. Posts that get the most interaction are pushed forward, and posts that don't fade to obscurity. That right there is going to push outrageous claims and crazy confrontations into everybody's view. That has to be fixed before all else.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-14 20:39

@zep Hm, I've never had these two together, but if I were to pick favorites right now I'd probably go with a Five Guys burger with a Kilt Lifter Scottish Ale.

@fosstodon

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-14 17:50

@GreyLinux FINALLY found a solution to this particular one. Apparently it's a bug in the latest version(s) of Phosh. Downgraded the version to 0.4.4-1 and it's working now.

sudo apt install phosh=0.4.4-1

Of course, now my head has that weird twisty feeling you get when you're trying to read something upside down for too long.

@PINE64

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-09 03:16

@codeHaiku I like driving, but that particular drive is not one of my favorites. It's through a lot of open range territory, and there's a lot of wild life. Doing that EXACT drive several years ago, I almost hit SEVERAL black cows in the dark that wandered onto the road. It's pure luck that I didn't hit at least one. Add sleeping kids to the mix so I couldn't blast my favorite music, and not a great trip.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-02 23:48

Mike Stone @mike 2020-10-02 22:02

@freddy @Decentralize_today It was totally us. The Particl account was opened, and dropped over 20 posts mostly about blockchain in less than a day. It was reported by our community as spam, and it acted like a spam account, so the account was removed. We're happy for people/projects to post links to their blogs, but it needs to be done in a way that sparks discussion and debate. Not just a dump of links. The account has been restored, and they're welcome here. Just please follow the CoC.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-28 06:20

Day 88 of the #100DaysToOffload Series:

A long long time ago (2001), I thought that Microsoft might be about to move to a Linux based OS.

I was wrong.

There are those (ESR) that think Microsoft might be about to do that now.

I think they're wrong.

https://mikestone.me/is-windows-turning-into-a-linux-distro

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-27 21:15

@mikepitt Welcome to Fosstodon. There's not really a search by email option. People can use services like Keybase to validate their accounts, but otherwise you kind of have to find your friends the old fashioned way. If you're interested in meeting new people, hashtags work like they do on Twitter, and the Trunk is a good source. A couple of good resources have been mentioned by others as well, which I'd recommend reading. Above all, don't hesitate to ask if you've got questions.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-23 18:38

@fosshermit Technically speaking, users CAN become their own ISPs if they so choose, but the time investment is significant, and you're still going to need to have a provider to connect yourself to the Internet at large. That's assuming you're not just looking to create services on a local area network. If you're looking to sell services, being an ISP is complicated by available infrastructure. You'd have issues providing services to others without them connecting via the Internet.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-23 18:35

@fosshermit Welcome to Fosstodon.

You're asking a lot of big questions here. When you say, "not possible to truly own your data except to keep it offline", I'd need some clarification on that. As long as your data is encrypted and no one other than you has the private key, I'd say you've maintained ownership. Only relying on remote backups and data retention would be an issue. In that case, I think it's more your'e relying on someone else, less that you don't own your data.

Mike Stone boosted
@fosshermit 2020-09-23 18:28

#introductions

I will probably be ignored but I have some questions:

Why is not possible to truly own your data except to keep it offline? what do I mean with this: why can't users become their own #ISP? why can't we buy some hardware, cut the cost of peering by everybody becoming a #Tier 1 ISP? What I'm missing here? I know is next to impossible but it's the only way of truly owning your hosting.

I'm not talking of free internet as free beer but of Freedom.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-22 19:41

@logrus1 Thank you! We appreciate any and all help we get from the community. Right now, Fosstodon is fully funded and we have no financial concerns. We keep six months of operating cost in backup, so if situations change and our income no longer meets our expenses, we have six months to resolve that issue before it becomes a problem. We've also done donations to open source projects when the amount of money we have in our backup funds reaches arbitrary limits.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-22 19:27

@floppy Also, the more I think about it, the less it feels like ActivityPub, but the service itself. Unless you're updating email services to connect via AcitivityPub instead of allowing, say, Mastodon to send emails. I don't know. Like I said, didn't think the whole thing through in detail. Just a weird idea that struck me.

@wizzwizz4 @john@liberdon.com

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-22 19:25

@floppy I looked at it more of a way to allow ActivityPub based services to interact with email. As was noted by @wizzwizz4, email is already a "federated" protocol, but it's not a protocol that's in our Fediverse. One of the cool things about ActivityPub is Mastodon can communicate with Pleroma, and Friendica. Adding email to that would be... interesting. Not sure it would be worth the effort.

@john@liberdon.com

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-22 19:20

@sultmhoor My description might leave a little bit to be desired.

@john@liberdon.com

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-22 19:12

@john@liberdon.com Well, I haven't given it a LOT of thought, but the idea as it occurred to me would be to enable services like Mastodon to interact with email by sending DMs with traditional syntax which would be converted to emails if there was no ActivityPub based account (Mastodon, Pleroma, etc). People receiving would be able to respond via their email which would appear as a response to the DM. Honestly dunno if it would work or be useful. Just a weird idea that struck me. Probably garbage.

@Gina I think that's probably true. Pavlovian conditioning is hard to get over, even when it's unintentional. In my high school, lunch started at 12:09PM. Every day. I went there for four years, so every week day for four years except during the summer, 12:09PM was lunch. I've been out of school now for over twenty years, and "LUNCH!" is the first thing I think about when I see 12:09 on the clock.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-17 22:45

@daremo Ah, that's a little harder to gauge. It does pretty good for your basic tasks, like weather, alarms, timers, etc. It can get a little dicey if you step outside the norms. There are a wide range of "skills" you can install (both manually and through automated processes) that extend its capabilities. As an American male with a pretty standard Midwestern accent, Mycroft almost always understands what I'm saying. Whether or not the skill is there to correctly answer is less of a sure thing.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-17 21:50

@daremo Well, the original Mark I was designed to run off of a Raspberry Pi 3. I can't remember which 3 right now, sorry. It's not as responsive as a Google or Amazon device, but it's still pretty quick. Of course, running on my X1 Carbon it's much quicker than running on a Pi 3. Everything is open source too, so if you find something that's not working to your liking, no barrier to changing it.

Mike Stone boosted
Kyle Rankin @kyle 2020-09-16 16:22

@aral Yes! Yes! Yes! This is key! So many projects ignore design and pick horrible defaults. In many cases the developer designs the interface as an external representation of their internal code (I'm looking at you iptables and tc). If you understand the code then it makes sense, otherwise *shrug*.

Good design requires empathy. You must think of how someone else would approach your software without understanding the code. If your defaults make a user shoot themselves in the foot, it's a bug.

Mike Stone boosted
Aral Balkan @aral 2020-09-16 15:39

Building tech for freedom?

Is it intuitive, easy to use, focused, and consistent?

Does it have beautiful defaults?

Is it:

- Private by default?
- Secure by default?
- Usable by default?

#design

Mike Stone boosted

Me: Is the monitor cable firmly plugged into the computer?

Her: ...

@indixotic@x0r.be I interviewed for a job back in 1995 where I spent over ten minutes of the interview "troubleshooting" a hypothetical printer. They sucked then, and they suck now. We have a term at my current job that makes things sound better than they are. Printers are an MVP, which means "Minimum Viable Product". Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 20:36

@nathand Of course, with Vivaldi, I can custom build my own. For example, !msocial uses Mastodon.social to search for hash tags. I can add f to my search shortcuts and type "f vivaldi", and that will use Fosstodon and search for any toots with the #Vivaldi hash. That's a lot easier than adding a new bang to DDG.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 20:32

@nathand I occasionally do that actually. Since DDG is my primary search provider in Vivaldi, I can use the ! syntax in the address bar and it still works. For example, I can type in the address of my browser, "!msocial Fosstodon" and it will bring up all the toots with the the Fosstodon hashtag. Pretty sweet deal.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 19:04

@tjb It's write.as. I don't self host, but if you're interested it's an option.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 18:32

@ghil It's one of the primary issues I have with Vivaldi. I do have Firefox, and I occasionally use it. I would love Gecko to be a configurable option in the browser, but that would probably require a lot more under the hood work than most of their options do.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 18:30

@zidanpragata I can, but as an open source project anybody can make a feature request, and me making that request wouldn't carry any more weight than anybody else doing it. If you'd like to put a feature request in, here's the best place to do it:

https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon/issues

Also, if you've got any skills in development, you can do the implementation yourself and submit it for the rest of us to use.

@ghil @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 18:00

@allien Thank you! That means a lot!

@kev @cooper @joseph @codesections @lee8oi @ohyran @Gina

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 17:59

Day 85 of the #100DaysToOffload Series:

I've been asked in the past why I choose Vivaldi as my browser. I tried, and failed, to put it succinctly into a blog post. Sorry about the wall of text.

https://mikestone.me/vivaldi

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 16:34

@centi I don''t know all the details on that. It's changing pretty often. Maybe @kev has some up to date figures?

@ghil

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 16:00

@ghil Yep, they absolutely could. In fact, that's pretty much what @kev and I did when we first created Fosstodon. We both started on another instance, and Kev messaged me one day and asked if I'd be interested in creating our own instance.

If you create your own instance, you can still follow all the same people. The only benefit of being on any particular instance (other than technical stuff like uptime) is the Local timeline. I'm pretty proud of ours here on Fosstodon.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 15:50

@yarmo Very cool! We're rooting for you!!

@cooper @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 15:48

@ghil Not sure, but Fosstodon is an English Only instance. We do require posts made to the local timeline be made in English. We believe this unifies the local timeline and helps maintain the community we have here, and it makes things easier for our team to moderate when we don't have to translate or understand nuance in however many languages.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 15:45

@zidanpragata We understand your desire to write in your primary language, but we keep Fosstodon English only for a couple of reasons we think are good ones. First, it unifies the Local Timeline. Second, it simplifies moderation for our team.

@kev

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-09 03:21

@yungbryanx Welcome aboard!

Mike Stone @mike 2020-09-02 15:49

@fossphorous I haven't personally tried it on zsh, but your timing is good. Previously I'd have said no, because it was written in bash, hence the name. Recently the developer migrated to Python, and there's a "new" version of it called Bpytop (not quite the same ring for the name). This version SHOULD work with Zsh, and according to the dev is "a lot faster and about a third as cpu heavy". Definitely worth trying if you're interested.

Mike Stone boosted
Mike Stone @mikestone 2020-08-28 23:12
It came! Bright, shiny new Pinebook Pro!
Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-28 20:58

@pheonix If you're using the multi-column version of the Mastodon UI (web), you can pin a hashtag as a column. Might be a good way to discover new people.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-28 15:40

@pheonix The best way is if you know the people you want to follow, you can search for them using the @ username @ servername.com format. You can also just search for the instance name and get a list of accounts (though far from comprehensive). Hashtags also work, and if all else fails, you can look in the Federated timeline for interesting subject matter. That's more of a firehose, so it's a little more difficult, but you can find some interesting content there if you're good at sifting.

aaaaaa

aaaAaa
aaAaaa
aAaaaa
Aaaaaa
AaaaaA
AaaaAa

Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-17 18:04

@benoitj Not really. No issues on our side except for a glitch with headphones. Zoom doesn't assume just because headphones are plugged in that you actually want to use them. You have to manually switch over to the headphones to get them to work. Otherwise, it just keeps right on using the speakers. That can be problematic with multiple kids in a single area. The other issues were with the school district's web portal getting demolished by traffic.

@nacro90 2020-08-10 04:48

Mastodon is a very interesting group of places. I started in mastodon.social to share my linux and foss journey. But it feels like twitter and I don't like twitter like most of mastodon users. Cooper :tor: :sadkev: @cooper 2020-08-07 15:25

We've had loads of new folks join Fosstodon, over the last few months. There are plenty of articles/blogs on FOSS friendly alternatives out there, and suggestions for such but, it'd be nice to hear from the community. What apps/alternatives are you using and why? What would you suggest for someone who's new to the FOSS scene? What have you discovered, based on your experiences?

Let's give our newer/unfamiliar members some community input and a few "pro tips" üòâ

#fosstodon #foss

Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-07 15:41

@mondstern Welcome aboard!

@fosstodon

Mike Stone boosted
Jake - Cosmic Nomad @cosmicnomad 2020-08-07 15:24

#introductions Howdy, my name's Jake and I've been a FOSS user for about a year now (Running GNU/Linux) and have thoroughly enjoyed the experience and community so far. I've followed a few prominent FOSS youtubers such as @distrotube@mastodon.technology and @christitus which has led me here! I hope to learn more and make some like-minded friends through Fosstodon. Best wishes to everyone!

Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-07 15:36

@neildarlow Yea, I actually used CDE on Digital Unix boxes back in college before I knew Linux existed. UI is still a very important thing for me. It's one of my peeves with many open source applications that they don't spend more time on the UI. Microsoft and Apple dedicate extensive resources to it and it shows in their presentation.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-07 15:19

@jrballesteros05 Sure thing.

:artix:

@hund @kev

Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-07 07:14

@ashwinvis Oh yea, for sure. I'm still a fan of LibreOffice, and like I said, I've been using it for as long as it's existed. It will continue to be my go-to office product on Linux and on Windows (when I have to).

Mike Stone @mike 2020-08-07 07:10

@ashwinvis Yes, and the "Tabbed" UI is probably my favorite when it comes to options in LibreOffice. I NEED to have the side bar open all the time, otherwise the white space is just overwhelming to me, but it's still the best choice in my opinion. That's not to say I think it's "good", because I still think all of the UI choices need some serious TLC, but it's the least bad option for me personally.

@oranje@cybre.space Unfortunately if the account was actually deleted, there's nothing even an admin can do to bring that account back. Accounts are a one time use, forever and ever. If it was just migrated to another instance, it can be reopened and used again, but deleted is deleted. Sorry.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-31 17:00

@_failsafe I actually learned some Powershell a few years back. I had a contractor job for a company, and there was a super repetitive task my department had to do there that took probably 30 minutes per instance. Being the lazy person I am, I wrote a Powershell script that took that manual process to a less than a second automated process. I showed it to my boss, and she loved it, but said they wouldn't use it because I was a contractor and there would be no one to support it after I left.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-25 06:02

@FundacionNanoVE What I would suggest is the Followers Only option. If you use that, your posts show up in the Home Timeline of anyone that follows you. It still doesn't show up in the Local Timeline or the Fed, but this permission level most closely resembles how a Twitter account works. If not showing up in the Federated timeline is a deal breaker for you, another instance might be the best option.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-23 23:59

@FundacionNanoVE Each toot can be changed on each individual toot by clicking on the globe down below the text field.

If you don't want to do it on a toot by toot basis, you can change it globally in your preferences here:

https://fosstodon.org/settings/preferences/other

Just adjust the settings to your liking in the "Posting Privacy" drop down box.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-23 23:50

@arlequin Thank you! I can't really speak to Windows servers as I have no real experience with them after 2010. I used to work as a Windows server application support tech, but that was a long time ago. And unfortunately I don't have a lot of experience with BSDs. That's really something I should rectify.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-23 23:48

@FundacionNanoVE Hi. If you're posting to the public timelines (specifically the local timeline) then we ask that you use English only. If you're posting as Unlisted, Followers Only, or using a DM, then you're free to use any language you're comfortable with. Please let me know if you have any questions about this policy.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-20 16:05

@joseph @codesections Ha! Yea, write.as seems to be holding up fine. There's a surprisingly rigorous debate on my use of the phrase, "unless you've been hiding under a rock the last week or so". Not the part of my article I expected to get much attention to be honest.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-20 16:01

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-20 16:00

@paladin I wouldn't say that it's impossible, but it would be pretty cumbersome with the given configuration. Each instance handles accounts on their instance and no other, so requiring approval from an admin of another instance that has no actual authority on your instance would be... odd. There could be a way to make that work that I'm just not thinking of.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-20 06:24

Mike Stone boosted
Mike Stone @mikestone 2020-07-20 00:06

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-19 22:22

@joseph Probably Hack A Day.

https://hackaday.com

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-19 21:25

@finlaydag33k In fairness, Mycroft uses a lot of Google services. They anonymize their traffic by funneling all Mycroft users through their systems, so Google has no way to differentiate. It's still not the greatest for privacy, but it's significantly better than using Google or Amazon outright.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-19 19:53

@mrksj I told my kids that too, but they seemed more interested in their Animal Crossing game. Only my oldest actually looked and saw it, but in fairness it took some effort with binoculars to even find it. It was amazing!

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-19 19:48

@finlaydag33k Mycroft does work with Home Assistant, and it's relatively easy to setup. Self hosting is an option, but the ease of setting up the self hosting option is questionable. It's definitely doable though.

@e8johan@mastodon.technology

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-19 06:58

Day 67 of the #100DaysToOffload Series:

https://mikestone.me/comet-neowise

Mike Stone boosted
Mike Stone @mikestone 2020-07-19 06:36
Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 21:20

@yarmo I usually use the web interfaces, because it's convenient. What was meant here was because I don't have install rights on my work computer, I couldn't use a client like Thunderbird if I wanted to (I don't), so it would force me to have a different work flow at work than I do at home, which I don't want.

Honestly, I put as little effort into email as I can. I don't care about 99% of the email I get, and I just want it out of the way in case a rare gem of a useful email appears.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 06:57

@jforseth210 I'll give it a look!

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 04:46

@Indie@x0r.be Yea, it's a little complex. I've been doing this for 3+ years, and there are some questions people ask me where I haven't the foggiest idea. And I'm an admin that's supposed to know what he's talking about!

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 04:44

@Citizenzibb And that's great, but the UI just makes me hate it. I'd rather use the gmail web interface than connect to it through Thunderbird.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 04:43

@g@mastodon.lol Nuts. I hate it when I do that. It should be resolved. The way those URLs are resolved is probably my least favorite write.as feature.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 03:05

@Indie@x0r.be No way to know for sure. Could have been picked up by a relay too. I don't know the exact config of your instance, so....

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 02:24

@Indie@x0r.be Neither actually. The federated timeline is all the toots of all the people who belong to instances your instance knows about. So, if you follow me, and no one else and your instance ONLY knows about the existence of Fosstodon, then your Federated timeline will be everybody from Fosstodon. If you then follow another person on another instance, so your instance now knows two instances, the Fed will be all the people from both those instances. Most instances know about a LOT of others.

Mike Stone @mike 2020-07-18 01:33

https://mikestone.me/trying-out-thunderbird-78

kungtotte @kungtotte 2020-07-06 04:49

@mike the funny thing about this too is that Windows is flat out buggy with regards to some hardware standards, but since they've got market dominance HW vendors start building to Windows' buggy implementation instead of the standard. So standards compliant OSes end up being overly buggy *for following the standard*.
